Today Congress opens the 115th session. Looking forward to continuing our hard work on behalf of #NY21:

I strongly believe that Members of Congress should serve as a model to the public for ethical and accountable behavior. This is why I am a leader in Congress when it comes to transparency and accountability, including posting my votes publicly to Facebook and releasing my personal financial information. I oppose the ethics amendment to the House rules and believe it should be removed from the rules package. I believe there need to be reforms to the ethics process but that they should be implemented on a bipartisan basis.

Yesterday I voted in support of H.Res. 5 - Adopting Rules for the One Hundred Fifteenth Congress. This resolution formally adopts the legislative rules for the next session of Congress. Critically, this resolution removed the amendment relating to the Office of Congressional Ethics and passed by a vote of 234-193.  Additionally, with my support, the House passed H.R. 27 – the Ensuring VA Employee Accountability Act, and H.R. 28 – the Biological Implant Tracking and Veteran Safety Act with strong bipartisan support.  Today I voted in support of H.R. 21 – the Midnight Rules Relief Act of 2017. This important legislation provides accountability and transparency to the American people. “Midnight Rules” are regulations, often high-cost or politically-driven, that are rushed into place in the last days and months of a presidential administration. This legislation provides Congress with the tools and flexibility to disapprove of poorly conceived rules that were put in place in the lame duck session of the Obama Administration, and paves the way for comprehensive regulatory reform. This legislation passed by a vote of 238-184.  Additionally, with my support, the House today passed six pieces of legislation with strong bipartisan support, including H.J.Res. 3 – a resolution approving the location of a memorial to commemorate and honor the members of the Armed Forces who served on active duty in support of Operation Desert Storm or Operation Desert Shield; H.R. 71 – the Taxpayers Right-To-Know Act; H.R. 73 – the Presidential Library Donation Reform Act; H.R. 70 – the Federal Advisory Committee Act Amendments of 2017; H.R. 72 – the GAO Access and Oversight Act; and H.R. 69 – the Thoroughly Investigating Retaliation Against Whistleblowers Act. All of these measures passed with strong bipartisan support.

The Medical Device Tax is a burdensome tax that creates undue harm to an industry that not only creates jobs, but also improves our health and well-being. Last Congress I fought hard to secure a delay in this tax that harms employers across our district and I'm proud to support permanently repealing this harmful tax on North Country medical device manufacturers.

Today I voted in support of H.R. 26, the Regulations from the Executive in Need of Scrutiny (REINS) Act. When I visit businesses across the North Country, one of the top concerns I hear about is the negative effects burdensome regulations from Washington have on their ability to grow and create jobs. The REINS Act pushes back against overregulation by federal bureaucrats and gives power back to the people by requiring that Congress vote on any major rule or regulation coming from the executive branch. This is a commonsense step for transparent and accountable government that will help grow our economy and create jobs for North Country families. This legislation passed the House by a vote of 237-187.  Additionally, today I voted in support of H. Res. 11, a bipartisan resolution objecting to United Nations Security Council Resolution 2334 as an obstacle to Israeli-Palestinian peace. Recently, in its’ waning days, the Obama Administration failed to uphold longstanding U.S. policy to oppose and veto any one-sided and anti-Israel resolutions at the UN Security Council. The U.S. has no greater ally in the region than Israel, and this UN resolution is biased against Israel, does not call upon the Palestinian Authority to fulfill their obligations to negotiations, and contributes to the boycott, divestment, and sanctions movement against Israel. This resolution calls for UN Security Council Resolution 2334 to be repealed or fundamentally altered so that it is no longer anti-Israel and it allows final status issues for a two-state solution to be resolved through direct bilateral negotiations between the Israelis and Palestinians. This resolution passed by a bipartisan vote of 342-80.

Today I voted in support of H.R. 5 – the Regulatory Accountability Act. Excessive federal regulations lead North Country families and businesses to pay higher prices, receive lower wages, and result in depressed economic growth. This important, bipartisan legislation simply requires the Executive Branch to adopt the least costly method to effectively implement the law. With the RAA, Congress and the President can work together to deliver real and permanent regulatory reform solutions for hardworking Americans. This legislation passed the House by a vote of 238-183.  Additionally, with my support, the House passed H.R. 39 - TALENT Act – legislation to codify the Presidential Innovation Fellows (PIF) Program. The PIF program was established in in 2012 to attract top innovators into government, capable of tackling issues at the convergence of technology, policy, and process. This legislation passed by a vote of 386-17.

I was proud to introduce two pieces of legislation to support military families: H.R. 279, the Military Family Stability Act and H.R. 282, the Military Residency Choice Act. Yesterday I voted in support of H.J. Res. 38 - a resolution disapproving the rule submitted by the Department of the Interior known as the Stream Protection Rule. The Office of Surface Mining Reclamation and Enforcement's (OSM) rulemaking process for the Stream Protection Rule lacked transparency of scientific records and studies and sought to enforce regulations beyond its jurisdiction. This resolution to disapprove passed by a vote of 228-194.  In the 114th Congress, I supported H.R. 1644, the Supporting Transparent Regulatory and Environmental Actions in Mining Act, which would restore transparency to the process of developing stream buffer zones near mining activities and require the Secretary of the Interior to work on a comprehensive study aimed at protecting streams. I look forward to supporting similar legislation this Congress.  Additionally, I voted in support of H.J. Res. 41 - a resolution providing for congressional disapproval under chapter 8 of title 5, U.S. Code, of a rule submitted by the Securities and Exchange Commission relating to "Disclosure of Payments by Resource Extraction Issuers". This rule is outside of the scope of the SEC's mission and compliance costs could reach $591 million, harming our energy sector and costing jobs. The resolution to disapprove passed by a vote of 235-187.

Pleased to reintroduce the Establishing Digital Interactive Transparency (EDIT) Act. The EDIT Act will instruct The Library of Congress to open up the legislative process by implementing a track changes style system for Congress.gov. This bill would make following the legislative process easier and will allow the American public to see at what stage in the process changes are made to legislation they are following. I'm proud that this bill has been supported by the Data Coalition--a leading group working to make government more open and transparent.

Additionally, this rule jeopardizes our national security by delaying the contracting process and threatening the resources our Armed Forces depend on to keep the country safe. The resolution to disapprove passed by a vote of 236-187.

Today I voted against H.J. Res. 36 – a resolution to overturn the Bureau and Land Management’s “Waste Prevention” rule to cap methane emissions. I support this rule which requires oil and gas companies to reduce venting, flaring and leaking of gas and dangerous pollutants from their operations on public and tribal lands using existing and readily available technology. Methane is a precursor to ground level ozone and an extremely potent greenhouse gas. Ground level ozone is extremely harmful to those with asthma, children, older adults, and outdoor workers and damage plants’ and forests’ ability to photosynthesize and grow. Additionally, ozone harms the Adirondack Park’s forest canopy and introduces smog and haze that damages views in the Park. This rule helps protect our environment in a responsible and economical way. Unfortunately, this resolution passed by a vote of 221-191.

It's an honor to serve as your Representative in Congress, and since being sworn into office, I have welcomed the opportunity to sit down with countless different groups of constituents, listening to their concerns on many important issues impacting their lives, their families, and their businesses in the 21st District.  In my first term alone, I participated in over 500 district events in addition to hosting hundreds of constituent meetings in my Washington office while in legislative session. We've also held nine telephone town halls where I am able to listen to and speak with tens of thousands of constituents to hear their concerns.   Having these respectful dialogues is important to me, and I believe they are the most effective way for me to take your voice and priorities to Congress.  And as I've done since I first became your Representative, over the coming months I will continue inviting groups of constituents and taking meetings in our Glens Falls, Plattsburgh, Watertown, and Washington, DC offices to listen and hear your concerns.  So far hundreds of groups have effectively advocated for their issues in this constructive format. And this week, my office will continue to be proactive in reaching out to numerous groups who have contacted us. Hearing their concerns and listening to their ideas is very important to me, even if we disagree.  I believe in free speech and our ability to gather together and make our voices heard; however, it’s unfortunate and counterproductive that a small number of activists believe the best way to address the very serious issues facing our country is to hijack and ambush community events for the sole purpose of political theater.  Many members of various protest groups have repeatedly harassed my hardworking staff and have personally targeted specific staff members. This type of intentionally disruptive behavior is unacceptable and unhelpful to civil public discourse. If it gets out of hand, we will continue to contact local law enforcement and U.S. Capitol Police.   These disruptions have challenged my staff’s ability to continue serving you - our constituents - on important casework regarding federal agencies. Because of these disruptions and calls from individuals outside of our district, we are planning to invest in additional resources to address the thousands of calls we receive each week - many of which are hourly callers. It is imperative that my staff is able to continue to focus on federal casework on behalf of the constituents of New York’s 21st District, and that my constituents understand that despite the efforts from these organized  disruptors, we will always continue our work to best serve you.  As has been our office policy from the beginning, if you'd like to request a meeting in my office, and are a constituent of the 21st Congressional District, please do so here:   https://stefanik.house.gov/contact/request-appearance.   My staff and I will work to respond to these requests as quickly as possible. I plan on posting weekly updates of the number of calls and letters my office has responded to on your behalf and for your transparency. My entire team is working hard to serve the 700,000+ constituents that I’m proud to represent. You are, and will always remain, my chief priority regardless of the counterproductive and disruptive efforts of a small group of special interests.

This bipartisan legislation directs the Secretary of the Interior to commission a gradient boundary survey of the Red River to identify the South Bank boundary between Texas and Oklahoma. The survey must be approved by Texas and Oklahoma and the legislation does not alter any tribes’ rights to mineral interest trust funds. This legislation passed by a vote of 250-171.

I have said all along that we must keep the parts of the Affordable Care Act that are working as we fix our broken healthcare system. This is why I have cosponsored H.R. 1121 -- the Pre-Existing Conditions Protection Act of 2017. This legislation aims to reaffirm guaranteed health care access, ensure that enrollees cannot have benefits excluded from a plan due to a pre-existing condition, and that patients will not pay more based on their health care status.  A 21st century healthcare system protects those who need care, and I am pleased to support this commonsense legislation as we work to build a healthcare system that increases access and lowers costs for families and businesses across our district.

This week I took part in a Congressional Delegation trip to Japan and the Republic of Korea required for new Members of the House Intelligence Committee.   This was an opportunity to highlight the importance of working with our allies in the region and to continue to build on our intelligence sharing capabilities. The House Intelligence Committee plays an important role in keeping our nation safe, and I was pleased to have the chance to visit with General Vincent Brooks, United States Forces Korea to learn more about the serious threats facing us.  During our trip, I also had the chance to meet and speak with a defector from North Korea who gave a first-hand account about what life is like in this rogue nation. I am grateful for the many opportunities to meet and thank the men and women in uniform who are downrange, for their service and sacrifice, including many from New York and who had previously been stationed at Fort Drum. Today I voted in support of H.R. 998 – the SCRUB Act. When I travel the district speaking to North Country businesses, one of the most frequent concerns they share with me is the need to reduce burdensome red tape so they can grow and hire more workers. I am committed to achieving comprehensive regulatory reform to grow our North Country economy and get families across our district good paying jobs. This bipartisan legislation establishes a commission -- independent from special interests and agencies -- to identify federal regulations that are duplicative, unnecessary, and costly to economic growth and the job market. This legislation passed by a vote of 240-185.   Additionally, today I voted in support of H.R. 1009 -- the OIRA Insight, Reform, and Accountability Act. This legislation codifies the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs’ (OIRA) role to review regulations. It also establishes transparency of the review process and requires OIRA to make available all information provided by the agency, the result of the review, and changes agencies made to a regulation while under review period. This legislation passed by a vote of 241-184.   I also voted in support of H.J. Res. 83 – a resolution disapproving the rule submitted by the Department of Labor relating to “Clarification of Employer's Continuing Obligation to Make and Maintain an Accurate Record of Each Recordable Injury and Illness.” This Obama Administration rule did not improve the health and safety of workers and only created regulatory uncertainty, especially for small businesses. Overturning this regulatory overreach permits the agency to work in better partnership with employers to advance workplace safety and health. This resolution of disapproval passed by a vote of 231-191.

Today I voted in support of H.R. 725 – the Innocent Party Protection Act. Small businesses have been victims of frivolous lawsuits simply because trial lawyers seek to keep a lawsuit in a preferred state court. Currently, standards among courts to determine jurisdiction vary and proving someone was added fraudulently is one of the heaviest burdens known to civil law. This bill establishes a uniform standard to determine if a defendant was falsely included and also permits a federal judge to remove a defendant from a lawsuit. This legislation passed by a vote of 224-194.   Additionally, I voted in support of H.R. 985 – the Fairness in Class Action Litigation and Furthering Asbestos Claim Transparency Act of 2017. This legislation ensures victims with legitimate claims receive justice and increases transparency of asbestos trusts to reduce fraud. This bill does not prevent a class action but provides fair rules for claimants. It also prevents abuses and ensures victims with legitimate claims maximize their recoveries before a lawyer gets paid. This legislation passed the House by a vote of 220-201.

Today, I voted in support of H.R. 1181, the Veterans 2nd Amendment Protection Act. This bipartisan bill preserves the 2nd Amendment rights of our nation’s brave Veterans and ensures that Veterans are given due process of law. It requires that a judicial authority make a determination if an individual is a danger to themselves or others rather than entrusting that decision to the Department of Veterans Affairs. This bipartisan legislation passed by a vote of 240-175.   Additionally, I voted in support of H.R. 1259 -- the VA Accountability First Act. This bipartisan bill seeks to reform the Department of Veterans’ Affairs (VA) and improve the care our heroes receive by giving the VA Secretary increased flexibility to remove, demote, or suspend any VA employee for performance or misconduct. Despite the serious and outrageous misconduct by employees at VA, it can still take several months or even more than a year to remove a permanent civil servant.  This bill maintains important whistleblower protections to prevent retaliation against VA employees. This legislation passed by a vote of 237-178.

This afternoon, I voted in support of H.R. 1367, bipartisan legislation to improve the Department of Veterans Affairs’ ability to hire and retain physicians and healthcare employees. Our veterans deserve the best care we can provide, and this bill will give the VA important tools to identify healthcare staffing shortages, recruit and retain high-quality employees, and quickly train new-hires. This bill passed the House by a bipartisan vote of 412-0. As the Representative of the district with more veterans than any other in New York State, I will continue to work to ensure that our veterans have access to the quality medical care that they have earned.

Friends, today I returned from a bipartisan Congressional Delegation visit to Afghanistan, the United Arab Emirates, Kuwait and Jordan.   As the Chair of the House Armed Services Subcommittee on Emerging Threats and Capabilities, this was an important opportunity for our delegation to conduct oversight of the policy, strategy, and resource issues associated with Operation Inherent Resolve in Iraq/Syria and Operation Resolute Support in Afghanistan.   The Emerging Threats and Capabilities Subcommittee has an important oversight role for counter-terrorism programs and initiatives and counter proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. Additionally, this subcommittee oversees U.S. Special Operations Forces, the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, information technology and programs, force protection policy and oversight, and related intelligence support. It makes sure that our nation is protected against terrorist attacks and unconventional threats.  Among our briefings and meetings, our delegation met with the Commander of all U.S. Special Operations Forces in Iraq and Syria for full updates on current and future operations to counter ISIS, including partnering engagements and operations with the units from the Iraqi Army and the Syrian Democratic Forces.  This trip was also a special opportunity to visit with our brave men and women in uniform deployed in this region. I had the opportunity to visit many constituents from our district, including servicemen and women from Greenwich, Plattsburgh, Star Lake, Schuylerville, Turin, Saranac Lake, Saratoga, Wilton, Cambridge, South Glens Falls, Lake George and Massena.  I thank my colleagues for joining me on this important Delegation visit, and most importantly, I thank all the brave men and women in uniform who are putting their lives at risk to keep us safe.

Today the House of Representatives took action in response to the "Marines United" scandal and passed H.R. 2052, the Protecting the Rights of Individuals Against Technological Exploitation (PRIVATE) Act. This bipartisan legislation I cosponsored amends the Uniform Military Code of Justice (UCMJ) to prohibit the wrongful distribution of nude images, and makes it a crime subject to punishment by court martial. The behavior of those involved with the ‘Marines United’ scandal is intolerable, and I am pleased to work with my colleagues on this commonsense reform to protect the privacy of our brave servicemembers.

Today I voted in support of H.R. 953, the Reducing Regulatory Burdens Act of 2017. This legislation will clarify that pesticides registered and properly used under the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide, and Rodenticide Act (FIFRA) do not require an additional Clean Water Act (CWA) permit for their use in or around navigable waters. For farmers, it is difficult and expensive to comply with the redundant federal and state permits under the CWA and FIFRA. This vote passed by a bipartisan vote of 256 - 165.  With my support, the House also passed H.R. 2052 – the PRIVATE Act, which would amend the Uniform Military Code of Justice (UCMJ) to prohibit the wrongful distribution of intimate images and subject any servicemember in violation to punishment by court-martial. This bill was drafted in response to the “Marines United” incident where members of our military were sharing illicit images of women without their consent. This bill passed by a bipartisan vote of 418 - 0.   I also voted in support of H.R. 467 – the VA Scheduling Accountability Act, which will improve appointment scheduling at VA medical centers by ensuring they are in compliance with the latest scheduling directives before receiving awards or bonuses. This bill passed by a bipartisan vote of  419- 0.  The House also passed by voice vote H.R. 1293, legislation to amend title 5, United States Code, to require that the Office of Personnel Management submit an annual report to Congress relating to the use of official time by Federal employees, and; H.R. 624 – the Social Security Number Fraud Prevention Act of 2017.

Today I voted in support of H.R. 10, the Financial CHOICE Act. This important legislation replaces the 2010 Dodd-Frank financial overhaul with a system that ends taxpayer funded bailouts once and for all and ensures no company remains “too big to fail”; holds Wall Street accountable with tough penalties for fraud and deception; and provides opportunities for small businesses, innovators and job creators by eliminating onerous regulations that stifle access to credit and capital.  When I meet with local financial institutions, one of the most frequent concerns I hear about is that Dodd-Frank has led to crippling government overreach and excessive regulation. The CHOICE Act pushes back against this excessive regulation so that our local financial institutions can give needed capital to allow our small businesses to thrive. Furthermore, this important legislation ends the ‘too big to fail’ framework that led us into trouble in the first place. I am committed to helping grow our North Country economy, and this legislation is a critical reform to aid our local businesses, innovators and job creators. This legislation passed the House by a vote of 233-186. Read more:

Today I voted in support of H.R.1215 - the Protecting Access to Care Act of 2017. This important legislation will bring needed tort reform to medical litigation laws, which will help lower health care costs for families and businesses in my district. Specifically, this legislation limits non-economic damages and limits the fees that lawyers can charge to maximize the award patients receive. This suffocating bureaucracy and inefficiency stifles growth, kills jobs and costs hard working North Country families money that should be kept in their pockets. It’s time for comprehensive tax reform.  During my meetings with constituents and businesses across our district, tax reform is a frequent topic of conversation, whether with families, manufacturers or our North Country farmers. I am soliciting feedback and input on this framework from stakeholders and hardworking families in the district. I applaud President Trump and my colleagues in Congress for making this a top priority and for unveiling this framework today, and I look forward to representing the North Country during the tax reform process. Today, I voted in support of H.R. 2792 – the Control Unlawful Fugitive Felons Act of 2017. This bill prohibits Supplemental Security Income (SSI) payments to individuals with outstanding felony warrants or parole violations. Under current law, a wanted felon is still eligible to receive government issued checks despite evading prosecution. North Country taxpayers shouldn’t be forced to fund fugitives evading justice, and this legislation is estimated to save the government more than $2.1 billion. This bill passed by a vote of 244-171.  Additionally, I voted in favor of H.R. 3823 - the Disaster Tax Relief and Airport and Airway Extension Act of 2017. This legislation provides temporary tax relief to the victims of Hurricanes Harvey, Irma, and Maria by allowing victims to deduct more of the cost of property damage and to grant easier access to retirement savings. It also encourages charitable giving by suspending the limitation on the deduction for charitable contributions. This legislation also reauthorizes the Federal Aviation Administration for six months. This bill passed the House by a bipartisan vote of 264-155.  Finally, with my support, the House passed S. 1866 - the Hurricanes Harvey, Irma, and Maria Education Relief Act of 2017, to help provide relief to students affected by the recent devastation in Texas, Florida, and Puerto Rico. This bill passed on a strongly bipartisan basis.

I also appreciated touring the new home for their expanding Code Blue shelter, which opened in 2014 and is critical for at-risk populations on cold North Country nights. Thanks to the Open Door for having us!

Yesterday I met with leaders from the 10th Combat Aviation Brigade (CAB) from Fort Drum. We discussed their recent deployment to Europe as the rotational CAB supporting European Command (EUCOM) and also had the opportunity to discuss the impact of deployments on military families in the North Country. We’re grateful that the 10th CAB continues to support our Nation by deploying across the globe. Thanks for stopping by!

Friends – I will be voting NO tomorrow on the final tax reform bill.  I support comprehensive tax reform that provides relief for families and businesses in our district. I voted against the tax bill when it first came before the House because it did not provide enough relief for New Yorkers.  While progress has been made during the conference committee, the final bill does not adequately protect the State and Local Tax deduction that so many in our district and across New York rely on. Due to Albany's failed leadership and inability to rein in spending, New York is one of the highest taxed states in the country, and families here rely on this important deduction to make ends meet. Failure to maintain SALT could lead to more families leaving our region.  I will be voting no on the final legislation and will continue to work hard to ensure that hard working families and small businesses have their priorities represented in Congress. I thank the many constituents across the district who have contacted my offices to share their opinions on this important legislation.
